issues.description: The problem statement (UML) specifies the attribute numberOfLecturers as type int, but the solution implementation declares numberOfLecturers as a byte and uses byte in the constructor and setter parameters. This is an attribute/type mismatch between the specification and the solution. Students reading the UML will implement numberOfLecturers as an int, while the reference solution uses byte — a discrepancy that can cause confusion when comparing implementations or when relying on the UML for correct types.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the types across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to declare numberOfLecturers as an int and update the constructor and setter parameter types to int, matching the UML and problem statement, or (B) if a byte was intentional, update the problem statement/UML to indicate numberOfLecturers: byte and document the reason. Option A is recommended to avoid surprising students (int is consistent with the rest of the integer attributes in the UML).
